abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic> is a causative gene for both autosomal dominant non-syndromic hearing loss (DFNA36) and autosomal recessive non-syndromic hearing loss (DFNB7/11). To date, 125 pathogenic variants in <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic> have been reported. Most of the <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic> variants are responsible for autosomal recessive hearing loss, with only 8 variants reported as causative for DFNA36. Here, we reported the prevalence of <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic>-associated hearing loss in a large non-syndromic hearing loss cohort of about 12,000 subjects. As a result, we identified 26 probands with <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic>-associated hearing loss, with the estimated prevalence of <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic>-associated hearing loss in the Japanese hearing loss cohort being 0.17% among all patients. Among the 26 probands with <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic>-associated hearing loss, 15 cases were identified from autosomal dominant hearing loss families. Based on the audiometric data from the probands, family members and previously reported cases, we evaluated hearing deterioration for DFNA36 patients. In addition, we performed haplotype analysis for 11 unrelated autosomal dominant hearing loss families carrying the same variant <jats:italic>TMC1</jats:italic>: NM_138691:c.1627G > A:p.Asp543Asn. The results clearly indicated that the same haplotype was present despite the families being unrelated, supporting the contention that this variant occurred by founder mutation.</jats:p>
